Project Number: 52260-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2018 
Islamic Republic of Pakistan: Capacity Building for 
Structural Transformation, Country Programming, 
and Portfolio Management 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 13112018134202512866 Generated Date: 17-Dec-2018 12:39:32 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support capacity building of 
Pakistan’s federal and provincial governments on the structural transformation, programming, and 
management of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) portfolio in Pakistan. 
 
2.  Initiated at the request of the Government of Pakistan, the TA will (i) facilitate the effective 
and efficient delivery of the development impacts of new structural reform initiatives; and (ii) 
deepen the anchoring of ADB’s country partnership strategy, country programming, and portfolio 
management in the government’s policies and strategies.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The Pakistan national election in July 2018 brought new challenges. The new government 
has taken over the reins of the country, yet it is still going through a process of converting its broad 
100-days agenda into a well-defined strategy and a plan in which the ADB program can be firmly 
placed. The government urgently needs to address the large budget and current account deficits, 
rising debt obligations, and falling foreign exchange reserves. The key challenges are to adopt 
the right reforms (e.g., tighten monetary policy, enhance the tax base, contain losses incurred by 
public sector enterprises, resolve the structural issues that undermine export competitiveness) 
and achieve good outcomes to sustain public support. The pace, quality, and extent of ADB’s 
pipeline in Pakistan depends on the speed at which the new government sets its overall and 
sector direction. For this the government requires quick analysis of previous experiences and 
assistance in developing broad and sector strategies and plans for the next 5 years.  
 
4.  ADB operations in Pakistan have expanded rapidly in 2015-2017 in almost all geographic 
areas of the country, covering energy, transport, agriculture, natural resources, rural development, 
finance, public sector management, and water and other urban infrastructure and services. As of 
30 September 2018, ADB had committed more than $32 billion in projects and TA to Pakistan. 
ADB’s active public sector portfolio in Pakistan had reached $6.90 billion, comprising 33 active 
investment projects financed from 40 ADB loans, 9 cofinanced grants, and 2 cofinanced loans. 
Cumulative contract awards had reached $3.12 billion and disbursements against commitments 
had reached $2.07 billion. Still, with more than 50% of the active portfolio to be contracted, the 
challenge for project implementation remains formidable. During country programming and/or 
portfolio review discussions, many key implementing agencies involved in ADB projects were 
found to lack effective understanding of ADB guidelines and procedures. Such institutional 
capacity deficiency can become a major impediment to the efficient and effective delivery of 
development projects. 
 
5.  Given the revolving nature of senior management roles in planning, finance, line ministries, 
public sector enterprises, and executing agencies, and limited technical training opportunities for 
those managers, targeted capacity enhancement is important as it will enable supervisory and 
regulatory bodies to better understand various facets of projects, including procurement and 
financial management. The complexity of development projects—in terms of project design, 
implementation, financial management, and procurement—often lends itself to situations where 
initiatives are stalled because of oversight requirements from the judiciary, anticorruption bodies, 
                                                
1  Following discussions with ADB Management during ADB’s 51st Annual Meeting in Manila, the Government of 
Pakistan, through its Economics Affairs Division, requested ADB via a letter dated 9 May 2018 to initiate a capacity 
building program for officials of the federal and provincial governments and autonomous bodies. The Prime Minister’s 
Office followed it up during a meeting with the Pakistan Resident Mission country director and the project team on 
19 September 2018. The vice-president (operations 1) approved the TA concept paper on 17 October 2018.

2 
and other regulators. While oversight is necessary and provides checks and balances, a lack of 
technical training for these entities further hinders projects and leads to delays. 
 
6.  The TA, with its overall focus on enhancing the government’s institutional capacity, will 
assist  the  government’s  structural  transformation  by  (i)  analyzing  current  and  emerging 
development and policy gaps and overlapping issues (country and/or sector diagnosis, public 
sector reforms), (ii) developing new innovations and sector plans and strategies (consultation and 
planning and/or strategic frameworks), and (iii) building government capacity to improve project 
quality  at  entry  (new  modalities,  instruments,  and  due  diligence requirements)  and  project 
management during the implementation stages (procurement and consultant recruitment, social 
and  environmental  safeguards,  gender  mainstreaming,  financial  management,  contract 
administration, and monitoring and evaluation). The impact of capacity development efforts under 
transaction TA is not usually sustained after a project ends because of the lack of institutional 
responsibility within relevant government departments or agencies. This highlights the need for 
systematic capacity building TA that provides this support broadly so as to develop a critical mass 
of people within the government who are not just project based but can effectively respond to 
portfolio challenges across sectors and geographic divisions. 
 
7.  The TA ties in with ADB’s Strategy 2030, which highlights the need to use TA resources 
to support capacity building and policy dialogue in developing member countries, as well as to 
pilot-test innovative approaches and solutions in specific areas or sectors.2 ADB will add value by 
combining finance, knowledge, and partnerships, and working closely with Pakistan governments 
at various levels to identify their needs and produce the most relevant knowledge, plans, and 
products. ADB will use the country partnership strategy and country portfolio review as the main 
platforms for defining customized support, promoting innovative technologies, and delivering 
integrated solutions by combining expertise across sectors and themes through a mix of public 
and private sector operations. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA will be the first of its kind in Pakistan to systematically address the capacity building 
demand of the government more broadly and respond to the knowledge support needs of key 
stakeholders in a coordinated manner. The TA is aligned with the following impact: development 
impacts of government reform initiatives and donor-supported operations delivered effectively and 
efficiently. The TA will have the following outcome: capacity of the Government of Pakistan to 
define its plans and actions increased and operational knowledge of executing and implementing 
agencies in programming and implementing ADB-supported projects improved.3 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Operational  guidelines  developed,  and  capacity  of  key  government 
agencies enhanced. This output will analyze the factors that hinder project delivery and carry 
out a training needs assessment of federal and local agencies responsible for programming, 
managing, and implementing ADB-financed projects through high-level government engagement. 
The TA team will prepare a consolidated and phased master capacity building approach with 
                                                
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
individual training plans and training course materials. With increasing accountability-oriented 
scrutiny for public sector investments, it is likewise important to improve the capacity of the 
oversight and judicial bodies to respond to issues related to development projects.4 To this end, 
this output will also identify the technical needs and gaps in the judicial and oversight systems of 
participating agencies to efficiently rule on the arbitration or assessment of development projects. 
This output will support the delivery of capacity building and training programs in institutional 
arrangements, thematic areas, and procedures in core project design and management functions 
such  as  country  programming,  project  preparation  and  readiness,  project  management, 
procurement, contract management, financial management, safeguards, gender, and auditing. 
 
10.  The TA team will develop an ADB Pakistan alumni network which includes Government 
officials in Pakistan who have received capacity building training through ADB support and 
establish a capacity assessment and monitoring system. With on-the ground engagement and 
support from ADB’s Pakistan Resident Mission, such a network will help maximize and sustain 
benefits beyond the capacity building training events, and provide government counterparts with 
valuable platforms of information exchange and connectivity. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Knowledge  products  and  advisory  support  for  the  government’s 
structural reforms and policy development delivered. This output will promote new priority 
areas (e.g., social safety nets, education, health, water, climate resilience, tourism, job creation, 
women’s economic empowerment, exports, and information technology). It will support the 
preparation of a policy paper on key priority sectors with recommendations to support policy 
changes and implementation. In line with ADB’s Strategy 2030, the policy papers will need to 
highlight innovative policies and mechanisms to support the implementation of ADB’s new 
products and modalities (e.g., quick-release project readiness financing, policy-based guarantees, 
financing facilities to support public–private partnerships, and small expenditure financing). 
 
12.  This output will provide need-based consulting services that will respond quickly and 
flexibly to changing or unforeseen circumstances and demands, and support just-in-time and 
best-practice knowledge products and services, as may be identified by the government and/or 
ADB. Thematic training programs and technical advisors will be provided on request to key 
ministries to help form relevant task forces and working groups and to provide action-oriented 
policy advice and road maps to help implement government reforms. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,200,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
14.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, facilities, domestic transportation, and 
other in-kind contributions. 
 
                                                
4  During project and portfolio review meetings, project officers have consistently noted the drawbacks and delays that 
were caused by the insufficient capacity and knowledge of the oversight bodies, including judicial bodies, on 
multilateral operations, procedures, and best practices for project management and implementation.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The Economic Affairs Division (EAD), Ministry of Finance, Revenue and Economic Affairs 
will be the executing agency responsible for liaising with Pakistani authorities and providing the 
strategic direction for TA implementation. ADB’s Pakistan Resident Mission will administer the TA 
and work closely with TA beneficiaries to ensure the effective use of TA resources. ADB and the 
EAD will hold quarterly and ad hoc TA coordination meetings to review and update the TA 
implementation status and to discuss emerging needs and opportunities for support under the TA 
together with the proposed work plans. All agreements reached by ADB and the EAD during the 
meetings will be documented, with the activities updated accordingly. 
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  January 2019–December 2021 
Executing agency  Economic Affairs Division, Ministry of Finance, Revenue and Economic 
Affairs

a  ADB. 2018. Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance. Project Administration Instructions. PAI 5.09. 
Manila. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.5 The TA will finance consulting services, studies, reports, and other knowledge 
products, as well as training, workshops, and other knowledge and learning events.6 Besides the 
consultants, the TA will engage resource persons to review the accuracy and quality of the reports, 
provide international perspectives, bring updated knowledge, and participate in and present at 
related workshops. The resource persons will include (i) an editor to refine the annual capacity 
development reports and edit knowledge products, and (ii) researchers to assist in conducting 
surveys and other tasks. 
 
                                                
5  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
6  The TA team will share such knowledge with the project teams and the alumni network through SharePoint and 
similar web-based tools or applications.

5 
18.  The training materials and programs will have the utmost impact on the success of the TA 
and  will  be  prepared  using  carefully  analyzed  international  best  practices.  To  reduce  the 
administrative burden and improve economy and efficiency, the capacity development training 
events will mainly be delivered at the National School of Public Policy, Pakistan Planning & 
Management Institute, National Institute of Banking & Finance and other public sector institutions. 
EAD will engage these institutions to host training events (including provision of selected training 
topics  and  other  support/facilities)  as  part  of  counterpart  in-kind  contribution.  International 
consultants and resource persons recruited separately by ADB will (i) lecture at most training 
events, and (ii) develop training materials and train the trainers of above public sector institutions 
to support follow-on training and information sharing, which will help ensure the sustainability of 
the intended capacity building. 
 
19.  The selection of government staff for the training programs will be done in consultation 
with the EAD. In general, preference will be given to middle- and lower-level management for 
project  implementation  training  programs,  and  to  senior  management  for  thematic  training 
programs  that  deal  with  policy  issues.  Detailed  selection  criteria  will  be  developed  during 
implementation in consultation with the EAD. 
 
20.  Consultants  will  prepare  an  annual  capacity  development  report  to  document  the 
improvement  in  the  portfolio  performance  of  ADB-assisted  projects,  the  training  programs 
conducted, feedback from participants, best practices, and the sector and thematic knowledge 
developed. The report will be published and disseminated to all stakeholders. 
 
21.  ADB’s  procurement.  Procurement  of  goods  and  equipment  will  follow  the  ADB 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB 
Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). The goods and equipment to be procured may 
include information technology equipment (such as computers, projectors, video conference 
facilities, drones and aerial photography systems), software, accessories, and other small office 
equipment. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Pakistan  for  Capacity  Building  for  Structural  Transformation,  Country 
Programming, and Portfolio Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Operational guidelines developed, and capacity of key government agencies enhanced 
1.1 Recruit first batch of consultants by 30 April 2019 
1.2 Design and complete training needs assessment and capacity development plan by 31 September 
2019 
1.3 Conduct at least 15 capacity building trainings by 2021 
1.4 Conduct at least three ADB business opportunities seminars cum Pakistan alumni network events by 
2021 
2.  Advisory support for the government’s structural reforms and policy development provided 
and knowledge on relevant sectoral and thematic issues enhanced 
2.1 Recruit first batch of consultants by 30 April 2019 
2.2 Identify the topics and scope of the knowledge products by 30 June 2019 
2.3 Conduct first knowledge event by 30 September 2019 
2.4 Complete first knowledge product by 31 March 2020

Development Bank (ADB) are presented in the table above. The government will provide counterpart support in the 
form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation}, and 
other in-kind contributions. The value of government contribution is estimated to account for 10% of the total TA cost. 
a  Financed by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
b  Includes information technology equipment such as computers, projectors, video conference facilities, drones and 
aerial photography systems, software, accessories, and other small office equipment. ADB will procure such

equipment procured will either be turned over to the government or disposed of following the project administration 
instructions on Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance (ADB. 2018. Administering Grant-Financed 
Technical Assistance. Project Administration Instructions. PAI 5.09. Manila).  
c  Includes (i) site visits to other ADB-funded projects for cross-learning, overseas training, and international study

representation costs (ADB [Budget, Personnel, and Management Systems Department; and Strategy, Policy and 
Review Department]. 2013. Use of Bank Resources: Regional Technical Assistance vs. Internal Administrative 
Expenses Budget. Memorandum. 26 June [internal]). Facilitators may be engaged as resource persons, and the 
travel cost of ADB staff acting as a resource person will be covered. Travel and per diem for participants and costs 
for external resource persons and peer reviewers for workshops and related activities will be provided for selected 
events. An advance may be provided, if appropriate and needed, for the administration of selected events, 
translation and interpretation services, and printing of documents and reports. 
d This covers passport and visa fees, in and out expenses, medical costs, other incidental travel expenses, 
interpretation costs, translation costs, and other miscellaneous allowances.
